{"uri": "2024-04-330749097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "03:12:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T03:12:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T03:02:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9529411792755127, "url": "https://canada.autonews.com/electric-vehicles/honda-nears-deal-canada-boost-ev-capacity-ontario-report-says", "title": "Honda nears deal with Canada to boost EV capacity in Ontario, report says", "body": "The deal, expected to be announced within a week, involves a multibillion-dollar commitment by Honda\n\nCanada is on the verge of an agreement with Honda Motor Co. that would see the Japanese firm build electric vehicles and their components in the province of Ontario, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe deal, expected to be announced within a week, involves a multibillion-dollar commitment by Honda for new facilities to process cathode active materials, build batteries, and assemble battery-powered vehicles -- making southern Ontario a key hub of company's EV manufacturing plans in North America. The Canadian government would subsidize a portion of the capital cost.\n\nHonda has a manufacturing plant in Alliston, Ontario, about an hour's drive north of Toronto, where it puts together Honda CR-V and Civic models. The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first US-made fully electric vehicles in Marysville, Ohio next year.\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10 per cent of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of electric vehicles in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centred on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen, Chrysler parent Stellantis and Sweden's Northvolt, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nEV ECOSYSTEM\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\nIn this case, the primary incentive, called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30 per cent of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10 per cent of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing -- if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a US $14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nKEEPING UP WITH U.S.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after U.S. President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the US.\n\nRead More: Subsidy Wars Heat Up With US Allies Forced to Pay Up or Lose Out\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of parts suppliers.\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the US enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.", "source": {"uri": "canada.autonews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first U.S.-made EVs in Marysville, Ohio, next year.\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10 percent of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of EVs in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centred on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen, Chrysler parent Stellantis and Sweden's Northvolt, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nEV ECOSYSTEM\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\nIn this case, the primary incentive, called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30 per cent of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10 per cent of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing -- if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a US $14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nKEEPING UP WITH U.S.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after U.S. President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the US.\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors, Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of suppliers.\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the U.S. enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.", "source": {"uri": "autonews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Automotive {"uri": "8090684405", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "02:02:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T02:02:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T02:02:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9372549057006836, "url": "https://auto.hindustantimes.com/auto/news/honda-nears-deal-with-this-country-to-boost-its-electric-vehicle-production-41713749535470.html", "title": "Honda nears deal with this country to boost its electric vehicle production", "body": "Canada is on the verge of an agreement with Honda Motor Co. that would see the Japanese firm build electric vehicles and their components in the province of Ontario, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe deal, expected to be announced within a week, involves a multibillion-dollar commitment by Honda for new facilities to process cathode active materials, build batteries, and assemble battery-powered vehicles -- making southern Ontario a key hub of company's EV manufacturing plans in North America. The Canadian government would subsidize a portion of the capital cost.\n\nHonda has a manufacturing plant in Alliston, Ontario, about an hour's drive north of Toronto, where it puts together Honda CR-V and Civic models. The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first US-made fully electric vehicles in Marysville, Ohio next year.\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10% of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of electric vehicles in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centred on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen AG, Chrysler parent Stellantis NV and Sweden's Northvolt AB, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\nIn this case, the primary incentive called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30% of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10% of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing -- if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a $14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after US President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the US.\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of parts suppliers.\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the US enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.\n\nJapanese automakers' new-vehicle sales in the US could increase 8% to 6 million units in 2024, we calculate, driven by improving vehicle supply, order backlogs and their aggressive new product offensive. It follows a 16% year-over-year jump to 5.54 million units in 2023 from 4.76 million units in 2022.", "source": {"uri": "auto.hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first US-made fully electric vehicles in Marysville, Ohio next year.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10% of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of electric vehicles in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centered on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen AG, Chrysler parent Stellantis NV and Sweden's Northvolt AB, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\nIn this case, the primary incentive, called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30% of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10% of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing -- if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a $14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after US President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the US.\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of parts suppliers.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the US enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.\n\nWhat Bloomberg Intelligence Says\n\nJapanese automakers' new-vehicle sales in the US could increase 8% to 6 million units in 2024, we calculate, driven by improving vehicle supply, order backlogs and their aggressive new product offensive. It follows a 16% year-over-year jump to 5.54 million units in 2023 from 4.76 million units in 2022.\n\n-- Bloomberg Intelligence auto analyst Tatsuo Yoshida", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", {"uri": "8090664995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "01:28:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T01:28:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T01:28:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/honda-nears-deal-with-canada-to-boost-electric-vehicle-capacity-1.2061871", "title": "Honda Nears Deal With Canada to Boost Electric Vehicle Capacity - BNN Bloomberg", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- Canada is on the verge of an agreement with Honda Motor Co. that would see the Japanese firm build electric vehicles and their components in the province of Ontario, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe deal, expected to be announced within a week, involves a multibillion-dollar commitment by Honda for new facilities to process cathode active materials, build batteries, and assemble battery-powered vehicles -- making southern Ontario a key hub of company's EV manufacturing plans in North America. The Canadian government would subsidize a portion of the capital cost.\n\nHonda has a manufacturing plant in Alliston, Ontario, about an hour's drive north of Toronto, where it puts together Honda CR-V and Civic models. The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first US-made fully electric vehicles in Marysville, Ohio next year.\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10% of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of electric vehicles in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nBig Take: Tesla Is Consumed by Chaos in Shift to Musk's Robotaxi Dream\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centered on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen AG, Chrysler parent Stellantis NV and Sweden's Northvolt AB, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\nIn this case, the primary incentive, called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30% of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10% of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing -- if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a $14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after US President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the US.\n\nRead More: Subsidy Wars Heat Up With US Allies Forced to Pay Up or Lose Out\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of parts suppliers.\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the US enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.\n\nWhat Bloomberg Intelligence Says\n\nJapanese automakers' new-vehicle sales in the US could increase 8% to 6 million units in 2024, we calculate, driven by improving vehicle supply, order backlogs and their aggressive new product offensive. It follows a 16% year-over-year jump to 5.54 million units in 2023 from 4.76 million units in 2022.\n\n-- Bloomberg Intelligence auto analyst Tatsuo Yoshida\n\nFor the full report, Bloomberg Terminal {"uri": "2024-04-331972525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "02:02:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T02:02:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T01:58:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/news/nation-world/national/article287924465.html", "title": "Honda nears deal with Canada to boost electric vehicle capacity", "body": "Canada is on the verge of an agreement with Honda Motor Co. that would see the Japanese firm build electric vehicles and their components in the province of Ontario, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe deal, expected to be announced within a week, involves a multibillion-dollar commitment by Honda for new facilities to process cathode active materials, build batteries, and assemble battery-powered vehicles - making southern Ontario a key hub of company's EV manufacturing plans in North America.\n\nThe Canadian government will subsidize a portion of the capital cost, the people said, speaking on condition they not be identified because the matter is still private.\n\nHonda has a manufacturing plant in Alliston, Ontario, about an hour's drive north of Toronto, where it puts together Honda CR-V and Civic models. The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first U.S.-made fully electric vehicles in Marysville, Ohio next year.\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10% of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of electric vehicles in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nHours after Bloomberg News reported the agreement, Ontario Premier Doug Ford appeared to confirm it, though he didn't mention Honda by name. \"This week we landed a new deal,\" he said Monday at a conference in Toronto. \"It'll be the largest deal in Canadian history. It'll be double the size of Volkswagen. So stay tuned, I'll be announcing it this week.\"\n\nFord was referring to a C$7 billion ($5.1 billion) Volkswagen AG battery assembly plant announced last year for southern Ontario.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centered on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen, Chrysler parent Stellantis NV and Sweden's Northvolt AB, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\n'Windows of opportunity'\n\nThe government's primary incentive, called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30% of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10% of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing - if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a $14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after U.S. President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the U.S.\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of parts suppliers.\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the U.S. enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.\n\n(With assistance from Mathieu Dion and Thomas Seal.)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-331517815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "15:24:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T15:24:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T15:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/honda-to-build-electric-vehicles-and-battery-plant-in-ontario-sources-say-1.6856693", "title": "Honda to build electric vehicles and battery plant in Ontario, sources say", "body": "Honda Canada is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant near its auto manufacturing facility in Alliston, Ont., where it also plans to produce fully electric vehicles.\n\nThe Canadian Press has learned that the federal and Ontario governments will make the announcement this week.\n\nSenior sources with information on the project confirmed the deal but were not yet able to give any dollar figures.\n\nOntario Premier Doug Ford on Monday morning told a First Nations conference that there will be an announcement this week about a new deal that he said will be double the size of a Volkswagen deal announced last year.\n\nThat EV battery plant set to be built in St. Thomas, Ont., comes with a $7-billion capital price tag.\n\nThe Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor, and while those two deals involved billions of dollars in production subsidies as a way of competing with the United States' Inflation Reduction Act subsidies, Honda's is expected to involve capital commitments and tax credits.\n\nFederal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada.\n\nThat's on top of an existing 30 per cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment.\n\nHonda's deal also involves two key parts suppliers for their batteries -- cathodes and separators -- with the locations of those facilities elsewhere in Ontario set to be announced at a later date.\n\nThe deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, the sources said.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau, Premier Doug Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 in Alliston when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the facility, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government.\n\nAround the time of that announcement, conversations began about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, the sources said, and negotiations began that summer.\n\nOntario Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli travelled to Japan that fall, the first of three visits to meet with Honda Motor executives about the project. Senior officials from the company in Japan also travelled to Toronto three times to meet with government officials, including twice with Ford.\n\nDuring a trip by the Honda executives to Toronto in March 2023, Ontario officials including Fedeli pitched the province as a prime destination for electric vehicle and battery investments, part of a strong push from the government to make Ford's vision of an end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain in the province a reality.\n\nNegotiations took a major step forward that July, when Ontario sent a formal letter to Honda Canada, signalling its willingness to offer incentives for a battery plant and EV production. Honda Canada executives then met with Ford in November and December.\n\nThe latter meeting sealed the deal, the sources said.", "source": {"uri": "toronto.ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8097045479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:48:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/484050/Honda-to-get-up-to-5B-in-government-assistance-for-EV-battery-assembly-plants", "title": "Honda to get up to $5B in government assistance for EV battery, assembly plants - Canada News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks during a tour of a Honda Manufacturing Plant in Alliston, Ont., Wednesday, April 5, 2023. Trudeau, Ontario Premier Doug Ford and Honda executives are expected to announce today that the Japanese automaker is building a multi-billion-dollar electric vehicle battery plant in Alliston, Ont.THE CANADIAN PRESS/Cole Burston\n\nHonda is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant next to its Alliston, Ont., assembly plant, which it is retooling to produce fully electric vehicles, all part of a $15-billion project that will include up to $5 billion in public money.\n\nThe two plants are expected to create 1,000 jobs on top of retaining the existing 4,200 jobs at the assembly plant. Once the vehicle facility is fully operational in 2028, it is set to produce up to 240,000 vehicles per year.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said Canada is able to attract major investments because it has great natural resources, clean energy, and skilled workers.\n\n\"Today's announcement is a game changer for manufacturing in Canada,\" he said during a press conference detailing the project on Thursday.\n\n\"Honda's investment is a vote of confidence in Canada, in Canadian auto workers, and in our manufacturing sector. Together, we're creating good-paying jobs, growing our economy, and keeping our air clean.\"\n\nThe deal does not involve production subsidies, which were used to woo two other automakers to build battery plants in Ontario instead of the United States with its incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nBut the federal government is set to give the Japanese automaker around $2.5 billion through tax credits.\n\nFederal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada.\n\nThat's on top of an existing 30 per cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment.\n\nOntario has committed to providing up to $2.5 billion directly - such as for capital costs - and indirectly, such as covering site servicing costs.\n\nThe $15-billion project includes the retooled plant, an electric vehicle battery plant nearby, as well as two key battery parts facilities located elsewhere in Ontario. Honda and POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. will build a cathode active material and precursor processing plant, and the automaker will also build a separator plant through a joint venture with Asahi Kasei Corporation.\n\nHonda's global CEO, Toshihiro Mibe, suggested the company is not stopping there.\n\n\"In the future, Honda will consider building a comprehensive battery chain beyond the four areas of EVs, EV batteries, cathode material and separators,\" he said, saying that battery recycling is key as well.\n\n\"Honda will realize low carbon value creation throughout the battery life cycle. In this way, Honda will establish a highly profitable business foundation and contribute to realizing a carbon neutral society.\"\n\nThe Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen in St. Thomas and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor.\n\nThe deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, which began after the last big government announcement at Honda's Alliston facility.\n\nTrudeau, Premier Doug Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the plant, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government.\n\nThat kickstarted conversations about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, and negotiations began that summer.\n\nIn the midst of those negotiations, in May of 2023, Stellantis and LG stopped construction on their $5-billion electric vehicle battery facility, as they pressed the federal government to match what the United States would offer under its then-new Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nThey ultimately reached a deal with Canada and Ontario that will see the companies receive performance incentives of up to $15 billion over about 10 years.\n\nThe offer was also extended to Volkswagen for its electric vehicle battery facility and that deal could see up to $13 billion in incentives.\n\nFreeland has said large production incentives were necessary for both Volkswagen and Stellantis to help establish Canada's green economy and ensure the companies were not lured away to the United States by the benefits under the IRA.\n\nThe federal government later indicated that tap was turned off, and Ontario Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli said in an interview that it didn't derail the negotiations with Honda.\n\n\"Production incentives were meant to match the American production incentives, but it's just far too much to continue with on an ongoing basis,\" he said.\n\n\"I think they were good to get started, but the rest of the industry now is starting to realize, right across North America, that you need to be where you really should be for the talent, clean energy and critical minerals.\"\n\nThe other two battery plants in the works have also started to draw other parts of the supply chain, Fedeli said, which became another part of the pitch for Honda - and perhaps others.\n\n\"We wanted EV manufacturers, we wanted a couple of battery manufacturers, and now we're filling in the major supply chain: cathode, anode, separator, electrolyte, copper foil, lithium hydroxide, those six major components,\" he said.\n\n\"We still have some room in our incentive packages for that line of six. After that, the incentive is: we brought you a customer. We brought you a battery maker ... You have to go and do your deal with them. You have enough incentive to come here.\"", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8097273124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "18:39:31", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T18:39:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T18:39:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.cheknews.ca/honda-to-get-up-to-5b-in-government-assistance-for-ev-battery-assembly-plants-1201031/", "title": "Honda to get up to $5B in government assistance for EV battery, assembly plants", "body": "Prime Minister Justin Trudeau (left to right), Honda executive Toshihiro Mibe and Ontario Premier Doug Ford walk along an assembly line at an event announcing plans for a Honda electric vehicle battery plant in Alliston, Ont., on Thursday, April 25, 2024.\n\nHonda is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant next to its Alliston, Ont., assembly plant, which it is retooling to produce fully electric vehicles as part of a $15-billion project to create a supply chain in the province for the Japanese automaker.\n\nThe plan - which includes up to $5 billion in public funds - is expected to see the two main plants create 1,000 jobs on top of retaining the existing 4,200 jobs at the assembly plant. That plant is set to produce up to 240,000 vehicles per year when fully operational in 2028.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said the jobs involved are at the heart of the deal.\n\n\"It's about, yes, creating green products that Canadians can rely on into the future, but it's primarily about investing in the workers and the communities that they are part of as these plants get built and as they work for generations to come,\" he said Thursday at a news conference detailing the project.\n\nThe deal does not involve production subsidies, which were used to woo two other automakers to build battery plants in Ontario instead of the United States with its incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nBut the federal government is set to give the Japanese automaker around $2.5 billion through tax credits.\n\nFederal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada.\n\nThat's on top of an existing 30 per cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment.\n\nOntario has committed to providing up to $2.5 billion directly - such as for capital costs - and indirectly, such as covering site servicing costs.\n\nTrudeau defended the public money that is being put toward the project, saying countries around the world are competing for investments in greener manufacturing and Honda's project will benefit Canada's economy and communities.\n\n\"That's not just creating jobs, great jobs for 1,000 new people around here, that's contributing to an ecosystem that will involve parts suppliers, it'll involve communities with vibrant art scenes and strong main streets, it'll involve future generations of Canada building the kinds of solutions the world needs,\" he said.\n\n\"Yes, there are politicians who sit back and say, 'No, no, no, no, no. We've got to balance the budget at all costs, even if it means not investing in Canadian workers and investing in the future.' Well, I think they're wrong.\"\n\nOntario Premier Doug Ford said Honda's investment is a generational commitment.\n\n\"This is decades and decades down the road,\" he said.\n\n\"What price do you put on that? There is no price you can put on that because we're investing into the people. The money is staying here in Ontario. It's not going overseas, it's not going down to the U.S., it's staying right here in Ontario for decades and generations to come.\"\n\nThe federal Opposition Conservatives suggested that other foreign companies that have received Canadian government subsidies have not filled their jobs with Canadian workers. Concerns have been raised about international workers being used to help build another EV battery plant in Windsor, Ont.\n\n\"We can't trust that his latest announcement of $5 billion in Canadian taxpayer money to another large multinational corporation will be any different,\" two critics wrote in a joint statement.\n\n\"Conservatives will not let Justin Trudeau sell out Canadian union workers and taxpayers yet again.\"\n\nThe $15-billion Honda project includes the retooled plant, an electric vehicle battery plant nearby, as well as two key battery parts facilities located elsewhere in Ontario. Honda and POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. will build a cathode active material and precursor processing plant, and the automaker will also build a separator plant through a joint venture with Asahi Kasei Corporation.\n\nHonda's global CEO, Toshihiro Mibe, suggested the company is not stopping there.\n\n\"In the future, Honda will consider building a comprehensive battery chain beyond the four areas of EVs, EV batteries, cathode material and separators,\" he said, noting that battery recycling is key as well.\n\n\"Honda will realize low carbon value creation throughout the battery life cycle. In this way, Honda will establish a highly profitable business foundation and contribute to realizing a carbon neutral society.\"\n\nThe Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen in St. Thomas, Ont., and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor.\n\nThe deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, which began after the last big government announcement at Honda's Alliston facility.\n\nTrudeau, Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the plant, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government.\n\nThat kickstarted conversations about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, and negotiations began that summer.\n\nIn the midst of those negotiations, in May of 2023, Stellantis and LG stopped construction on their $5-billion electric vehicle battery facility, as they pressed the federal government to match what the United States would offer under its then-new Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nThey ultimately reached a deal with Canada and Ontario that will see the companies receive performance incentives of up to $15 billion over about 10 years.\n\nThe offer was also extended to Volkswagen for its electric vehicle battery facility and that deal could see up to $13 billion in incentives.\n\nFreeland has said large production incentives were necessary for both Volkswagen and Stellantis to help establish Canada's green economy and ensure the companies were not lured away to the United States by the benefits under the IRA.\n\nThe federal government later indicated that tap was turned off, and Ontario Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli said in an interview that it didn't derail the negotiations with Honda.\n\n\"Production incentives were meant to match the American production incentives, but it's just far too much to continue with on an ongoing basis,\" he said.\n\n\"I think they were good to get started, but the rest of the industry now is starting to realize, right across North America, that you need to be where you really should be for the talent, clean energy and critical minerals.\"\n\nThe other two battery plants in the works have also started to draw other parts of the supply chain, Fedeli said, which became another part of the pitch for Honda - and perhaps others.\n\n\"We wanted EV manufacturers, we wanted a couple of battery manufacturers, and now we're filling in the major supply chain: cathode, anode, separator, electrolyte, copper foil, lithium hydroxide, those six major components,\" he said.\n\n\"We still have some room in our incentive packages for that line of six. After that, the incentive is: we brought you a customer. We brought you a battery maker ... you have to go and do your deal with them. You have enough incentive to come here.\"", "source": {"uri": "cheknews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CHEK"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_battery", {"uri": "8091897957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "17:50:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T17:50:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T17:49:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://energynow.ca/2024/04/honda-nears-deal-with-canada-to-boost-electric-vehicle-capacity/", "title": "Honda Nears Deal with Canada to Boost Electric Vehicle Capacity", "body": "Canada is on the verge of an agreement with EV deal Honda Motor Co., sources tell Bloomberg. PHOTO BY MANDEL NGAN/AFP/GETTY IMAGES\n\nBy Brian Platt\n\nCanada is on the verge of an agreement with Honda Motor Co. that would see the Japanese firm build electric vehicles and their components in the province of Ontario, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe deal, expected to be announced within a week, involves a multibillion-dollar commitment by Honda for new facilities to process cathode active materials, build batteries, and assemble battery-powered vehicles -- making southern Ontario a key hub of company's EV manufacturing plans in North America. The Canadian government would subsidize a portion of the capital cost.\n\nHonda has a manufacturing plant in Alliston, Ontario, about an hour's drive north of Toronto, where it puts together Honda CR-V and Civic models. The company makes hybrid vehicles at factories in Ohio and Indiana, according to its website, and it plans to start manufacturing its first U.S.-made fully electric vehicles in Marysville, Ohio next year.\n\nThe Honda investment comes at an anxious moment for the auto sector, with consumer adoption of electric vehicles playing out slowly in some regions because of high prices and a shortage of charging stations. Tesla Inc. is cutting more than 10 per cent of its global workforce, Chinese producer BYD Co. reported a sharp drop in deliveries of electric vehicles in the first quarter, and other automakers have delayed EV investments.\n\nStill, manufacturers are making long-term bets. Last month, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. announced a plan to collaborate on technology for battery-based electric vehicles, including software, as they seek to keep up with Chinese rivals.\n\nThe negotiations between Honda and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government have taken many months and centred on investment tax credits, or ITCs, as the means by which the government will help pay for the capital costs of the factories. It will differ from the agreements Canada struck last year with Volkswagen AG, Chrysler parent Stellantis NV and Sweden's Northvolt AB, the people said; those companies were offered billions of dollars over a period of years to subsidize battery production.\n\nTrudeau's government will tout the Honda deal as a success story directly related to those contracts, one government official said. Those agreements created an ecosystem around Canada's EV supply chain, attracting other auto firms and allowing the government to transition to its own system of tax incentives, officials within the Trudeau administration will say.\n\nIn this case, the primary incentive, called the clean technology manufacturing ITC, provides a refundable tax credit for 30 per cent of equipment costs. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's budget last week also introduced a new tax credit that would apply to 10 per cent of the cost of buildings used for electric vehicle manufacturing -- if a company has significant portions of its EV supply chain within Canada.\n\nFreeland was closely involved in the Honda negotiations and the new EV tax credit was specifically geared to landing the Japanese firm, according to people familiar with the discussions, though other EV companies will also qualify if they build enough of their supply chain in Canada.\n\nThe Honda deal doesn't include ongoing production subsidies of the type received by Volkswagen and Stellantis, according to people who spoke with Bloomberg about it. They declined to divulge the total estimated cost of government support.\n\nEarlier this year, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei reported that Honda was considering a US$14 billion investment in Canada, but hadn't made a decision yet. A spokesperson for Honda in Canada did not reply to a request for comment Sunday.\n\nTrudeau's government has argued that large taxpayer support for automakers is necessary to ensure that Canada maintains its share of the North American auto business after U.S. President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law in 2022, providing financial help for firms building EVs in the U.S.\n\nThe auto sector is particularly important to Ontario, Canada's largest province by population and home to assembly plants owned by Ford Motor Co., General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp., and Stellantis, as well as scores of parts suppliers.\n\n\"The windows of opportunity for this kind of thing are short,\" Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne told Bloomberg in a recent interview discussing last year's subsidy deals. He said the government had to act after the U.S. enacted the Inflation Reduction Act, or risk losing the plants south of the border. \"That window was there and we seized it.\"\n\nStellantis and partner LG Energy Solution are in the middle of building a battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, across the border from Detroit. Volkswagen's proposed site is southwest of Toronto and Northvolt's is near Montreal. Canada's subsidy packages for those companies are being partially paid by provincial governments in Ontario and Quebec.", "source": {"uri": "energynow.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Energy News {"uri": "8091722086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "15:30:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T15:30:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T15:30:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/business/2024/04/22/honda-to-build-electric-vehicles-and-battery-plant-in-ontario-sources-say/", "title": "Honda to build electric vehicles and battery plant in Ontario, sources say - Medicine Hat News", "body": "Honda Canada is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant near its auto manufacturing facility in Alliston, Ont., where it also plans to produce fully electric vehicles. A general view of production along the Honda CRV production line is shown during a tour of the Honda plant in Alliston on Wednesday, Apr. 5, 2023. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Cole BurstonTORONTO - Honda Canada is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant near its auto manufacturing facility in Alliston, Ont., where it also plans to produce fully electric vehicles. The Canadian Press has learned that the federal and Ontario governments will make the announcement this week. Senior sources with information on the project confirmed the deal but were not yet able to give any dollar figures. Ontario Premier Doug Ford on Monday morning told a First Nations conference that there will be an announcement this week about a new deal that he said will be double the size of a Volkswagen deal announced last year. That EV battery plant set to be built in St. Thomas, Ont., comes with a $7-billion capital price tag. The Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor, and while those two deals involved billions of dollars in production subsidies as a way of competing with the United States' Inflation Reduction Act subsidies, Honda's is expected to involve capital commitments and tax credits. Federal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada. That's on top of an existing 30 per cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment. Honda's deal also involves two key parts suppliers for their batteries - cathodes and separators - with the locations of those facilities elsewhere in Ontario set to be announced at a later date. The deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, the sources said. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, Premier Doug Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 in Alliston when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the facility, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government. Around the time of that announcement, conversations began about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, the sources said, and negotiations began that summer. Ontario Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli travelled to Japan that fall, the first of three visits to meet with Honda Motor executives about the project. Senior officials from the company in Japan also travelled to Toronto three times to meet with government officials, including twice with Ford. During a trip by the Honda executives to Toronto in March 2023, Ontario officials including Fedeli pitched the province as a prime destination for electric vehicle and battery investments, part of a strong push from the government to make Ford's vision of an end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain in the province a reality. Negotiations took a major step forward that July, when Ontario sent a formal letter to Honda Canada, signalling its willingness to offer incentives for a battery plant and EV production. Honda Canada executives then met with Ford in November and December. The latter meeting sealed the deal, the sources said. This report by The Canadian Press was first published April 22, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8091893313", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "17:46:27", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T17:46:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T17:45:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/honda-build-electric-vehicles-battery-151611913.html", "title": "Honda to build electric vehicles and battery plant in Ontario, sources say", "body": "TORONTO -- Honda Canada is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant near its auto manufacturing facility in Alliston, Ont., where it also plans to produce fully electric vehicles, The Canadian Press has learned.\n\nSenior sources with information on the project confirmed the federal and Ontario governments will make the announcement this week, but were not yet able to give any dollar figures.\n\nHowever, comments Monday from Ontario Premier Doug Ford and Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli suggest it is a project worth around $14 billion or $15 billion.\n\nFord told a First Nations conference that there will be an announcement this week about a new deal he said will be double the size of a Volkswagen deal announced last year. That EV battery plant set to be built in St. Thomas, Ont., comes with a $7-billion capital price tag.\n\nFedeli would not confirm if Ford was referencing Honda, but spoke coyly after question period Monday about the amount of electric vehicle investment in the province.\n\n\"We went from zero to $28 billion in three years and if the premier, if his comments are correct, then next week, we'll be announcing $43 billion ... in and around there,\" he said.\n\nThe Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor, and while those two deals involved billions of dollars in production subsidies as a way of competing with the United States' Inflation Reduction Act subsidies, Honda's is expected to involve capital commitments and tax credits.\n\nFederal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10-per-cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada.\n\nThat's on top of an existing 30-per-cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment.\n\nHonda's deal also involves two key parts suppliers for their batteries -- cathodes and separators -- with the locations of those facilities elsewhere in Ontario set to be announced at a later date.\n\nThe deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, the sources said.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau, Premier Doug Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 in Alliston when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the facility, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government.\n\nAround the time of that announcement, conversations began about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, the sources said, and negotiations began that summer.\n\nFedeli travelled to Japan that fall, the first of three visits to meet with Honda Motor executives about the project. Senior officials from the company in Japan also travelled to Toronto three times to meet with government officials, including twice with Ford.\n\nDuring a trip by the Honda executives to Toronto in March 2023, Ontario officials including Fedeli pitched the province as a prime destination for electric vehicle and battery investments, part of a strong push from the government to make Ford's vision of an end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain in the province a reality.\n\nNegotiations took a major step forward that July, when Ontario sent a formal letter to Honda Canada, signalling its willingness to offer incentives for a battery plant and EV production. Honda Canada executives then met with Ford in November and December.\n\nThe latter meeting sealed the deal, the sources said.\n\nHonda approached the federal government a few months ago, a senior government official said, and Freeland led her government's negotiations with the company.\n\nThe project is expected to involve the construction of several plants, according to the source.\n\n- With files from Nojoud Al Mallees in Ottawa.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published April 22, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, {"uri": "8097214635", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:53:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:53:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:53:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/honda-to-get-up-to-5b-in-government-assistance-for-ev-battery-assembly-plants-1.2064357", "title": "Honda to get up to $5B in government assistance for EV battery, assembly plants -  BNN Bloomberg", "body": "If you build it, they will come, but it didn't happen for electric vehicles: Stein\n\nHonda is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant next to its Alliston, Ont., assembly plant, which it is retooling to produce fully electric vehicles as part of a $15-billion project to create a supply chain in the province for the Japanese automaker.\n\nThe plan - which includes up to $5 billion in public funds - is expected to see the two main plants create 1,000 jobs on top of retaining the existing 4,200 jobs at the assembly plant. That plant is set to produce up to 240,000 vehicles per year when fully operational in 2028.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said the jobs involved are at the heart of the deal.\n\n\"It's about, yes, creating green products that Canadians can rely on into the future, but it's primarily about investing in the workers and the communities that they are part of as these plants get built and as they work for generations to come,\" he said Thursday at a news conference detailing the project.\n\nThe deal does not involve production subsidies, which were used to woo two other automakers to build battery plants in Ontario instead of the United States with its incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nBut the federal government is set to give the Japanese automaker around $2.5 billion through tax credits.\n\nFederal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada.\n\nThat's on top of an existing 30 per cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment.\n\nOntario has committed to providing up to $2.5 billion directly - such as for capital costs - and indirectly, such as covering site servicing costs.\n\nTrudeau defended the public money that is being put toward the project, saying countries around the world are competing for investments in greener manufacturing and Honda's project will benefit Canada's economy and communities.\n\n\"That's not just creating jobs, great jobs for 1,000 new people around here, that's contributing to an ecosystem that will involve parts suppliers, it'll involve communities with vibrant art scenes and strong main streets, it'll involve future generations of Canada building the kinds of solutions the world needs,\" he said.\n\n\"Yes, there are politicians who sit back and say, 'No, no, no, no, no. We've got to balance the budget at all costs, even if it means not investing in Canadian workers and investing in the future.' Well, I think they're wrong.\"\n\nOntario Premier Doug Ford said Honda's investment is a generational commitment.\n\n\"This is decades and decades down the road,\" he said.\n\n\"What price do you put on that? There is no price you can put on that because we're investing into the people. The money is staying here in Ontario. It's not going overseas, it's not going down to the U.S., it's staying right here in Ontario for decades and generations to come.\"\n\nThe federal Opposition Conservatives suggested that other foreign companies that have received Canadian government subsidies have not filled their jobs with Canadian workers. Concerns have been raised about international workers being used to help build another EV battery plant in Windsor, Ont.\n\n\"We can't trust that his latest announcement of $5 billion in Canadian taxpayer money to another large multinational corporation will be any different,\" two critics wrote in a joint statement.\n\n\"Conservatives will not let Justin Trudeau sell out Canadian union workers and taxpayers yet again.\"\n\nThe $15-billion Honda project includes the retooled plant, an electric vehicle battery plant nearby, as well as two key battery parts facilities located elsewhere in Ontario. Honda and POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. will build a cathode active material and precursor processing plant, and the automaker will also build a separator plant through a joint venture with Asahi Kasei Corporation.\n\nHonda's global CEO, Toshihiro Mibe, suggested the company is not stopping there.\n\n\"In the future, Honda will consider building a comprehensive battery chain beyond the four areas of EVs, EV batteries, cathode material and separators,\" he said, noting that battery recycling is key as well.\n\n\"Honda will realize low carbon value creation throughout the battery life cycle. In this way, Honda will establish a highly profitable business foundation and contribute to realizing a carbon neutral society.\"\n\nThe Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen in St. Thomas, Ont., and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor.\n\nThe deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, which began after the last big government announcement at Honda's Alliston facility.\n\nTrudeau, Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the plant, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government.\n\nThat kickstarted conversations about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, and negotiations began that summer.\n\nIn the midst of those negotiations, in May of 2023, Stellantis and LG stopped construction on their $5-billion electric vehicle battery facility, as they pressed the federal government to match what the United States would offer under its then-new Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nThey ultimately reached a deal with Canada and Ontario that will see the companies receive performance incentives of up to $15 billion over about 10 years.\n\nThe offer was also extended to Volkswagen for its electric vehicle battery facility and that deal could see up to $13 billion in incentives.\n\nFreeland has said large production incentives were necessary for both Volkswagen and Stellantis to help establish Canada's green economy and ensure the companies were not lured away to the United States by the benefits under the IRA.\n\nThe federal government later indicated that tap was turned off, and Ontario Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli said in an interview that it didn't derail the negotiations with Honda.\n\n\"Production incentives were meant to match the American production incentives, but it's just far too much to continue with on an ongoing basis,\" he said.\n\n\"I think they were good to get started, but the rest of the industry now is starting to realize, right across North America, that you need to be where you really should be for the talent, clean energy and critical minerals.\"\n\nThe other two battery plants in the works have also started to draw other parts of the supply chain, Fedeli said, which became another part of the pitch for Honda - and perhaps others.\n\n\"We wanted EV manufacturers, we wanted a couple of battery manufacturers, and now we're filling in the major supply chain: cathode, anode, separator, electrolyte, copper foil, lithium hydroxide, those six major components,\" he said.\n\n\"We still have some room in our incentive packages for that line of six. After that, the incentive is: we brought you a customer. We brought you a battery maker ... you have to go and do your deal with them. You have enough incentive to come here.\"", "source": {"uri": "bnnbloomberg.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "BNN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8091742717", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "15:45:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T15:45:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T15:45:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/honda-to-build-electric-vehicles-and-battery-plant-in-ontario-cp-sources-say-1.2061871", "title": "Honda to build electric vehicles and battery plant in Ontario, CP sources say - BNN Bloomberg", "body": "Canada has a once-in-a-generation opportunity on EV battery supply chains: consultant\n\nHonda Canada is set to build an electric vehicle battery plant near its auto manufacturing facility in Alliston, Ont., where it also plans to produce fully electric vehicles.\n\nThe Canadian Press has learned that the federal and Ontario governments will make the announcement this week.\n\nSenior sources with information on the project confirmed the deal but were not yet able to give any dollar figures.\n\nOntario Premier Doug Ford on Monday morning told a First Nations conference that there will be an announcement this week about a new deal that he said will be double the size of a Volkswagen deal announced last year.\n\nThat EV battery plant set to be built in St. Thomas, Ont., comes with a $7-billion capital price tag.\n\nThe Honda facility will be the third electric vehicle battery plant in Ontario, following in the footsteps of Volkswagen and a Stellantis LG plant in Windsor, and while those two deals involved billions of dollars in production subsidies as a way of competing with the United States' Inflation Reduction Act subsidies, Honda's is expected to involve capital commitments and tax credits.\n\nFederal Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's recent budget announced a 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit on the cost of buildings related to EV production as long as the business invests in assembly, battery production and cathode active material production in Canada.\n\nThat's on top of an existing 30 per cent Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit on the cost of investments in new machinery and equipment.\n\nHonda's deal also involves two key parts suppliers for their batteries -- cathodes and separators -- with the locations of those facilities elsewhere in Ontario set to be announced at a later date.\n\nThe deal comes after years of meetings and discussions between Honda executives and the Ontario government, the sources said.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau, Premier Doug Ford and Honda executives were on hand in March 2022 in Alliston when the Japanese automaker announced hybrid production at the facility, with $131.6 million in assistance from each of the two levels of government.\n\nAround the time of that announcement, conversations began about a larger potential investment into electric vehicles, the sources said, and negotiations began that summer.\n\nOntario Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli travelled to Japan that fall, the first of three visits to meet with Honda Motor executives about the project. Senior officials from the company in Japan also travelled to Toronto three times to meet with government officials, including twice with Ford.\n\nDuring a trip by the Honda executives to Toronto in March 2023, Ontario officials including Fedeli pitched the province as a prime destination for electric vehicle and battery investments, part of a strong push from the government to make Ford's vision of an end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain in the province a reality.\n\nNegotiations took a major step forward that July, when Ontario sent a formal letter to Honda Canada, signalling its willingness to offer incentives for a battery plant and EV production. Honda Canada executives then met with Ford in November and December.\n\nThe latter meeting sealed the deal, the sources said.", "source": {"uri": "bnnbloomberg.ca", "dataType": "news", "title":
