"2015-12-", "textStart": 2125, "textEnd": 2132}], "sentiment": 0.05098039215686279, "wgt": 176, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8096931885", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:34:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:34:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:33:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://itnewsonline.com/PRNewswire/Honda-Plans-to-Establish-Comprehensive-Electric-Vehicle-Value-Chain-in-Ontario-Canada/985442", "title": "Honda Plans to Establish Comprehensive Electric Vehicle Value Chain in Ontario, Canada", "body": "ALLISTON, ON, April 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ - Honda Motor Co., Ltd. today announced that it plans to build a comprehensive EV value chain in Canada with an approximate investment of CAD$15 billion (USD$11 billion), including investment by joint venture partners, to strengthen its EV supply system and capability to prepare for a future increase in EV demand in North America. Honda has begun evaluating the requirements to build an innovative and environmentally responsible Honda EV plant and a stand-alone Honda EV battery plant in Alliston, Ontario. The proposed Honda EV value chain will also include a cathode active material and precursor (CAM/pCAM) processing plant through a joint venture partnership with POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. and a separator plant through a joint venture partnership with Asahi Kasei Corporation, with announcements to follow in their respective Ontario communities.\n\nHonda expects that electric vehicle production will begin in 2028. Once fully operational, the EV plant will have a production capacity of 240,000 EVs per year and the EV battery plant will have a capacity of 36 GWh per year. In addition to securing the current employment level of 4,200 associates at its two existing manufacturing facilities in Ontario, Honda estimates it will add a minimum of 1,000 new associates for the EV and EV battery manufacturing facilities. The investment in the new facilities will also create significant spinoff jobs across all sites, including in the construction sector.\n\nHonda has begun the process of evaluating the scope of its investment and completing negotiations with its joint venture partners. This work is expected to be finalized during the next six months and more details will be shared at that time.\n\nTo support this project, Honda is collaborating with the governments of Canada and Ontario to drive innovation in low-emissions manufacturing by accessing performance-based initiatives available through the federal government's new Investment Tax Credits and provincial direct and indirect incentives.\n\nStriving to realize carbon neutrality for all its products and corporate activities by 2050, Honda has set a goal to make BEVs and FCEVs represent 100% of vehicle sales by 2040. To achieve this goal, Honda will continue offering attractive products in this electrified era globally, including its largest market of North America.\n\nAs the first step in achieving this electrification goal in North America, Honda positioned its existing auto production plants in the state of Ohio in the U.S. as its EV Hub for production, including the retooling of existing plants, an investment of USD$700 million, and the construction of a joint venture EV battery plant with LG Energy Solution, with an expected investment of USD$4.4 billion.\n\nThe Ohio EV hub will serve as the foundation for future EV and EV battery production, sharing knowledge and expertise with other Honda plants in North America, including the new EV assembly and battery plants in Ontario, Canada. Honda expects EV production to begin at the Marysville Auto Plant in late 2025.\n\nAs a second step in this initiative, Honda will strive to establish a comprehensive EV value chain that includes all aspects of EV production in Canada, from the procurement of raw materials mainly for batteries, to the production of finished EVs. Honda will leverage EV production knowledge learned at the Ohio EV Hub, combined with the abundant resources and clean energy available in Canada, to establish a stable supply system for batteries, the key component of EVs, and increase cost competitiveness of its EVs as a whole.\n\nFor more information, photos and future updates, please visit www.hondanews.ca.\n\nComments by Toshihiro Mibe, Global CEO of Honda:\n\n\"Honda is making progress in our global initiatives toward the realization of our 2050 carbon neutrality goal. In North America, following the initiative to establish our EV production system capability in the U.S., we will now begin formal discussions toward the establishment of a comprehensive EV value chain here in Canada, with the support of the governments of Canada and Ontario. We will strengthen our EV supply system and capability with an eye toward a future increase in EV demand in North America.\"\n\nComments by Jean Marc Leclerc, President and CEO of Honda Canada Inc.:\n\n\"Honda of Canada Manufacturing is one of the premier automotive manufacturing facilities in the world and for nearly forty years, our work has been guided by determination, innovation, and a relentless drive to evolve. Today's announcement is a historic investment by a manufacturer in the Canadian auto industry. It proudly honours the highly skilled associates who have earned a global reputation for manufacturing excellence and represents Honda's recognition of the long-term attractiveness of the Canadian electric vehicle manufacturing ecosystem.\"\n\nHonda Motor Co., Ltd. is responsible for the development, production and sales of automobiles, motorcycles, power products and aviation products worldwide. Honda now delivers over 28 million products annually through its three product lines. Honda and its partners build products in more than 60 manufacturing plants in 27 countries, employing about 197,000 associates globally. On a global basis by 2050, Honda is striving to achieve carbon neutrality for all products and corporate activities, as well as zero traffic collision fatalities involving Honda automobiles and motorcycles.\n\nHonda Canada Inc. was founded in 1969 and is the parent company for both Honda and Acura vehicle brands in Canada. Since 1986, the company has produced Honda engines and more than 10 million cars and light trucks at its Alliston, Ontario manufacturing facilities, where Honda Civic and Honda CR-V are currently built. Honda has invested over $6.5 billion in Canadian operations, and each year sources over $3 billion in goods and services from Canadian suppliers. Since its inception, Honda Canada has sold over five million Honda and Acura passenger cars and light trucks in Canada through a dealer network of more than 280 dealerships across the country. For more information, please visit www.hondacanada.ca.\n\nHonda of Canada Mfg. (HCM) began production in Alliston, Ontario in November 1986 and is Honda's only manufacturing facility in Canada. HCM's plants sit on 890 acres, encompass approximately 4 million square feet, and employ 4,200 associates. The plants have the capacity to produce more than 400,000 vehicles each year combined. HCM manufactures two of Honda's best-selling models, the Honda Civic and the CR-V, and produced its 10 millionth vehicle in 2023. For more information, please visit www.hondacanadamfg.ca.", "source": {"uri": "itnewsonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "IT News Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8097091218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:19:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:19:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/business/honda-set-11-billion-electric-vehicle-battery-plants-canada-4292511", "title": "Honda to set up $11 billion electric vehicle, battery plants in Canada", "body": "TOKYO : Honda Motor plans to invest C$15 billion ($11 billion) in new EV and battery production plants alongside its existing facilities in Ontario, it said on Thursday, the Japanese automaker's largest ever investment in Canada.\n\nThe investment, announced by company executives and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, signals Honda's expectation for more growth in North American demand for EVs.\n\nLike other Japanese car companies, Honda has been a relative latecomer to EVs, and is now pushing to better compete with fast-moving Chinese rivals.\n\nIn Canada, it intends to produce essential EV components through joint ventures with companies such as Asahi Kasei, setting up a production system that covers everything from materials to finished vehicles.\n\nOperations are targeted to start by 2028, with annual production capacity estimated to be a maximum of 240,000 EVs and 36 gigawatt-hours for batteries.\n\nAlthough global EV demand has slowed, Honda executive Shinji Aoyama told reporters the supply network would help Honda achieve its goal for all of its North American sales to be either EVs or fuel cell vehicles by 2040.\n\nHonda said it expects to contribute 60 per cent-70 per cent of the total investment, with the rest coming from joint venture partners and Ontario government subsidies.\n\nSupport from the federal Canadian government and Ontario could total around C$5 billion, Trudeau's office said. Details of the investment are due to be finalised later this year.\n\nThe EV and battery plants will be constructed adjacent to existing four-wheeled vehicle and engine plants and the total workforce will increase by around 1,000 people from 4,200 now, Honda said.\n\nIt also announced a plan to work with South Korean steel giant POSCO for the production of battery cathode materials, and with Asahi Kasei to make separators.\n\nBy handling everything from material development to vehicle assembly in Ontario - including bringing battery production in house and sourcing locally - Honda expects to reduce costs by more than 20 per cent from current methods.\n\nCanada has wooed companies involved in all parts of the EV supply chain to bolster its manufacturing heartland in Ontario as the world seeks to cut carbon emissions.\n\n\"Honda's investment is a vote of confidence in Canada, in Canadian auto workers, and in our manufacturing sector. Together, we're creating good-paying jobs, growing our economy, and keeping our air clean,\" Trudeau said.\n\nNorth America accounts for approximately 30 per cent of Honda's global four-wheeled vehicle sales.\n\nHonda is currently overhauling facilities at its U.S. plant in Ohio, with an investment of $700 million, and constructing a battery plant in a joint venture with LG Energy Solution for $4.4 billion.\n\n(Additional reporting by David Ljunggren in Ottawa; Editing by David Dolan, Mark Potter, Elaine Hardcastle)", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-04-335300875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:10:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:10:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:10:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/Press+Releases/Honda+Plans+to+Establish+Comprehensive+Electric+Vehicle+Value+Chain+in+Ontario%2C+Canada/23116072.html", "title": "Honda Plans to Establish Comprehensive Electric Vehicle Value Chain in Ontario, Canada", "body": "ALLISTON, ON, April 25, 2024 /CNW/ - Honda Motor Co., Ltd. today announced that it plans to build a comprehensive EV value chain in Canada with an approximate investment of CAD$15 billion, including investment by joint venture partners, to strengthen its EV supply system and capability to prepare for a future increase in EV demand in North America. Honda has begun evaluating the requirements to build an innovative and environmentally responsible Honda EV plant and a stand-alone Honda EV battery plant in Alliston, Ontario. The proposed Honda EV value chain will also include a cathode active material and precursor (CAM/pCAM) processing plant through a joint venture partnership with POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. and a separator plant through a joint venture partnership with Asahi Kasei Corporation, with announcements to follow in their respective Ontario communities.\n\nHonda expects that electric vehicle production will begin in 2028. Once fully operational, the EV plant will have a production capacity of 240,000 EVs per year and the EV battery plant will have a capacity of 36 GWh per year. In addition to securing the current employment level of 4,200 associates at its two existing manufacturing facilities in Ontario, Honda estimates it will add a minimum of 1,000 new associates for the EV and EV battery manufacturing facilities. The investment in the new facilities will also create significant spinoff jobs across all sites, including in the construction sector.\n\nHonda has begun the process of evaluating the scope of its investment and completing negotiations with its joint venture partners. This work is expected to be finalized during the next six months and more details will be shared at that time.\n\nTo support this project, Honda is collaborating with the governments of Canada and Ontario to drive innovation in low-emissions manufacturing by accessing performance-based initiatives available through the federal government's new Investment Tax Credits and provincial direct and indirect incentives.\n\nStriving to realize carbon neutrality for all its products and corporate activities by 2050, Honda has set a goal to make BEVs and FCEVs represent 100% of vehicle sales by 2040. To achieve this goal, Honda will continue offering attractive products in this electrified era globally, including its largest market of North America.\n\nAs the first step in achieving this electrification goal in North America, Honda positioned its existing auto production plants in the state of Ohio in the U.S. as its EV Hub for production, including the retooling of existing plants, an investment of USD$700 million, and the construction of a joint venture EV battery plant with LG Energy Solution, with an expected investment of USD$4.4 billion.\n\nThe Ohio EV hub will serve as the foundation for future EV and EV battery production, sharing knowledge and expertise with other Honda plants in North America, including the new EV assembly and battery plants in Ontario, Canada. Honda expects EV production to begin at the Marysville Auto Plant in late 2025.\n\nAs a second step in this initiative, Honda will strive to establish a comprehensive EV value chain that includes all aspects of EV production in Canada, from the procurement of raw materials mainly for batteries, to the production of finished EVs. Honda will leverage EV production knowledge learned at the Ohio EV Hub, combined with the abundant resources and clean energy available in Canada, to establish a stable supply system for batteries, the key component of EVs, and increase cost competitiveness of its EVs as a whole.\n\nFurthermore, with an eye toward secondary use and the recycling of batteries, Honda will realize low-carbon value creation throughout the entire battery life cycle, through which Honda will establish a highly profitable business foundation and contribute to the realization of a carbon-neutral society.\n\nFor more information, photos and future updates, please visit www.hondanews.ca.\n\nComments by Toshihiro Mibe, Global CEO of Honda:\n\n\"Honda is making progress in our global initiatives toward the realization of our 2050 carbon neutrality goal. In North America, following the initiative to establish our EV production system capability in the U.S., we will now begin formal discussions toward the establishment of a comprehensive EV value chain here in Canada, with the support of the governments of Canada and Ontario. We will strengthen our EV supply system and capability with an eye toward a future increase in EV demand in North America.\"\n\nComments by Jean Marc Leclerc, President and CEO of Honda Canada Inc.:\n\n\"Honda of Canada Manufacturing is one of the premier automotive manufacturing facilities in the world and for nearly forty years, our work has been guided by determination, innovation, and a relentless drive to evolve. Today's announcement is a historic investment by a manufacturer in the Canadian auto industry. It proudly honours the highly skilled associates who have earned a global reputation for manufacturing excellence and represents Honda's recognition of the long-term attractiveness of the Canadian electric vehicle manufacturing ecosystem.\"\n\nHonda Motor Co., Ltd. is responsible for the development, production and sales of automobiles, motorcycles, power products and aviation products worldwide. Honda now delivers over 28 million products annually through its three product lines. Honda and its partners build products in more than 60 manufacturing plants in 27 countries, employing about 197,000 associates globally. On a global basis by 2050, Honda is striving to achieve carbon neutrality for all products and corporate activities, as well as zero traffic collision fatalities involving Honda automobiles and motorcycles.\n\nHonda Canada Inc. was founded in 1969 and is the parent company for both Honda and Acura vehicle brands in Canada. Since 1986, the company has produced Honda engines and more than 10 million cars and light trucks at its Alliston, Ontario manufacturing facilities, where Honda Civic and Honda CR-V are currently built. Honda has invested over $6.5 billion in Canadian operations, and each year sources over $3 billion in goods and services from Canadian suppliers. Since its inception, Honda Canada has sold over five million Honda and Acura passenger cars and light trucks in Canada through a dealer network of more than 280 dealerships across the country. For more information, please visit www.hondacanada.ca.\n\nHonda of Canada Mfg. (HCM) began production in Alliston, Ontario in November 1986 and is Honda's only manufacturing facility in Canada. HCM's plants sit on 890 acres, encompass approximately 4 million square feet, and employ 4,200 associates. The plants have the capacity to produce more than 400,000 vehicles each year combined. HCM manufactures two of Honda's best-selling models, the Honda Civic and the CR-V, and produced its 10 millionth vehicle in 2023. For more information, please visit www.hondacanadamfg.ca.", "source": {"uri": "streetinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "StreetInsider.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": C$15M EV production hub in Ontario, Canada", "body": "Honda Motor (NYSE:HMC) announced it is investing C$15 million (US$11 million) to build four new manufacturing plants in Ontario, Canada, to build out its electric vehicle capabilities.\n\nThe automaker said it has started the evaluation process for a Honda EV plant and a stand-alone Honda EV plant in Alliston, Ontario.\n\nIt also plans to build a cathode active material and precursor (CAM/pCAM) processing plant through a joint venture partnership with POSCO Future M and a separator plant through a joint venture partnership with Asahi Kasei Corporation.\n\nHonda said it expects that EV production will kick off in 2028 and, once fully operational, the EV plant will have a production capacity of 240,000 EVs per year and the EV battery plant will have a capacity of 36 GWh per year.\n\n\"In North America, following the initiative to establish our EV production system capability in the US, we will now begin formal discussions toward the establishment of a comprehensive EV value chain here in Canada, with the support of the governments of Canada and Ontario,\" Honda CEO Toshihiro Mibe said in a statement.\n\n\"We will strengthen our EV supply system and capability with an eye toward a future increase in EV demand in North America.\"\n\nThe investment was welcomed by Canada's prime minister Justin Trudeau and Ontario premier Doug Ford.\n\n\"This investment is a strong vote of confidence in Canada and Ontario's highly skilled workers, strong economies, and competitive business environments,\" Ford's office said in a {"uri": "8096999802", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:17:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:17:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:16:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://republicofmining.com/2024/04/25/trudeau-and-ford-unveil-hondas-plan-to-build-four-new-factories-in-ontario-by-robert-benziequeens-park-and-rob-ferguson-toronto-star-april-25-2024/", "title": "Trudeau and Ford unveil Honda's plan to build four new factories in Ontario - by Robert BenzieQueen's Park and Rob Ferguson (Toronto Star - April 25, 2024)", "body": "The Japanese automaker will have an electric vehicle factory and auto assembly plant in a region where they have been making gasoline-powered cars and trucks since 1986.\n\nThis Honda accord is worth a cool $15 billion. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Premier Doug Ford announced Thursday that Honda will build four new factories in Ontario, producing 240,000 electric vehicles as the Japanese auto giant expands its footprint.\n\nFuelled by $5-billion in public money, the expansion will create 1,000 new jobs at Honda, which already employs 4,200 people in Alliston, plus thousands of spinoff positions in parts production and construction of the new facilities.\n\nHonda, which has been building cars in Ontario since 1986, said the new EV assembly plant will open in 2028. The initiative also an EV battery factory in Alliston and two supporting facilities to be located elsewhere in Ontario that will make battery components in joint ventures with other Japanese and Korean companies. {"uri": "2024-04-335048130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:44:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:44:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:44:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://canada.autonews.com/manufacturing/honda-spending-15-billion-new-ev-assembly-battery-output-ontario", "title": "Honda spending $15 billion on new EV assembly, battery output in Ontario", "body": "Honda currently builds the CR-V, above, and Civic in Alliston, Ont.\n\nHonda Motor Co. will announce today its plan to build an integrated electric-vehicle battery supply chain in Canada from the ground up with a series of investments in Ontario worth a combined $15 billion, Automotive News Canada has confirmed with multiple sources close to the negotiations between the automaker and governments.\n\nThe Japan-based automaker will confirm at an event the long-rumoured plans that will greatly expand its Canadian footprint at an event at its manufacturing campus in Alliston, Ont., about 90 kilometres north of Toronto.\n\nThe company's global leadership will join Honda Canada President Jean-Marc Leclerc and a wide range of government officials, including Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Ontario Premier Doug Ford, for the announcement that has been more than two years in the making.\n\nThe Canadian Press and Bloomberg reported similar details.\n\nThe spending blitz includes new EV assembly and battery-cell plants at the company's Alliston campus, where Honda currently builds the CR-V and Civic. The assembly plant will have capacity to build 240,000 vehicles per year, while the battery plant will be capable of producing 36 GWh of EV batteries. The expansion will create 1,000 direct jobs, as well as retain the 4,200 staff already employed at the site.\n\nHonda will also invest in two joint-venture supplier plants in yet-to-be-disclosed cities elsewhere in the province. One plant with South Korea-based partner Posco Future M will produce precursor and cathode active material for Honda's battery cells. The other, headed by Japan-based chemical company Asahi Kasei, will produce battery separators. Standalone announcements that include full details of both facilities will be made at later dates, but in a separate announcement April 25, Asahi Kasei said it plans to build a roughly $1.5-billion separator plant in Ontario that will open in 2027.\n\nRECORD INVESTMENT\n\nThe $15 billion in combined spending sets a new high-water mark for Canadian automotive investment, eclipsing Volkswagen Group's $7-billion commitment to build a sprawling battery-cell plant in St. Thomas, Ont. made just over a year ago.\n\nThe EV battery plant planned for Alliston is the fourth battery plant Canada has secured over the past two years, as both federal and provincial governments work overtime to establish the country as a key battery and EV production hub.\n\nIn addition to Volkswagen's plans, Sweden-based Northvolt said it would build a $7-billion cell plant outside Montreal in September 2023. A joint venture between South Korea battery-cell maker LG Energy Solution and Stellantis made the first battery commitment to Canada in March 2022; the companies are now well into construction on a $5-billion cell site in Windsor, Ont.\n\nHonda's plans are the most highly integrated of the four battery plants, with the automaker playing an active role in EV assembly, battery manufacturing and battery component production. This will qualify Honda for the new 10 per cent Electric Vehicle Supply Chain investment tax credit proposed in the 2024 federal budget.\n\nThe federal government pledged up to $2.5 billion in investment tax credits to support Honda's set of projects, while the Ontario government will contribute up to a matching $2.5 billion in direct and indirect incentives.\n\nThe capital-spending support for Honda differs from the three battery-cell manufacturing deals previously struck by Ottawa, which were structured to match production subsidies offered in the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). The federal government estimates costs for those three deals will total $37.7 billion over the next decade.\n\nThe EV supply chain spending will vastly increase Honda's presence in Canada, where it currently builds its CR-V crossover, Civic sedan and four-cylinder engines.\n\nNEW PRODUCT UNKNOWN\n\nThe company did not specify which future products it will build in Alliston, but auto analyst Sam Fiorani forecasts Honda will begin production of a small electric crossover at its campus in 2027, after production of the current Civic has run its course. An electric crossover from luxury brand Acura will follow in 2028, he added.\n\nFiorani, the vice-president of global vehicle forecasting at U.S.-based AutoForecast Solutions, projects CR-V production will continue in Alliston through these changes.\n\nThe investment will also supercharge Honda's North American electrification efforts.\n\nThe automaker, which has long been criticized as an EV laggard, premiered the Honda Prologue, its first battery-electric vehicle available in Canada, this spring. The crossover is built by General Motors in Mexico and underpinned by the U.S. automaker's Ultium architecture, but Honda's in-house EVs are scheduled to follow starting in 2025.\n\nUp until this point, however, Honda's North American electrification efforts have centred on the United States. It formed a joint venture with LG Energy Solution to build a US$4.4 billion battery plant in Ohio in early 2023, as well as committed $700 million to retool several local plants to build EVs.", {"uri": "8091876102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "17:30:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T17:30:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T17:30:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/politics/honda-makes-multibillion-dollar-deal-to-build-electric-vehicle-factory-in-ontario-sources/article_26092a72-00b6-11ef-a10e-771e5f73c646.html", "title": "Honda makes multibillion-dollar deal to build electric vehicle factory in Ontario: sources", "body": "OTTAWA -- Japanese automaker Honda has agreed to establish a major new, multibillion-dollar electric vehicle operation in Ontario, according to two federal government sources.\n\nThe deal is expected to be announced this week at Honda's existing factory in Alliston, north of Toronto, where the company will reveal plans to bring a \"massive project\" to Ontario for the manufacturing of electric vehicles, batteries and other components, a government source with knowledge of the situation told the Star.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe source said the deal is worth billions of dollars, and would be based on federal funding through investment tax credits -- rather than direct subsidies worth billions of dollars that attracted other automakers, including Volkswagen and Stellantis, to set up EV battery plants in Ontario -- along with unspecified support from the provincial government.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA second federal government source confirmed the Honda agreement is coming, but did not provide any details.\n\nMedia reports revealing the deal prompted Premier Doug Ford to hail what he described as the \"largest deal\" yet in his government's push -- alongside Ottawa and Qu\u00e9bec -- to attract companies to set up manufacturing in Canada for the emerging industry of electric vehicle and their components.\n\nSpeaking in Toronto, Ford said Honda's investment in Alliston would dwarf the massive Stellantis electric vehicle battery factory in Windsor and the even larger Volkswagen project in St. Thomas, each of which received billions of dollars in subsidies from Queen's Park and the federal government.\n\nSwedish battery manufacturer Northvolt has also committed to building a battery mega-factory outside Montreal, with $4.6 billion in subsides from Ottawa and Quebec City.\n\n\"Over the past three years alone, we've attracted over $28 billion in auto and EV battery investments -- and folks, stay tuned,\" Ford told the First Nations Major Projects Coalition meeting Monday.\n\n\"But this week, we landed a new deal. It will be the largest deal in Canadian history. It'll be double the size of Volkswagen so stay tuned, we'll be announcing it this week,\" the premier enthused.\n\nFord noted Stellantis was spending $5 billion on a 4.2-million-square-foot facility in Windsor, and VW another $7 billion on a 16-million-square-foot gigafactory in St. Thomas that will be the fourth largest building in the world.\n\n\"Ontario now is the only place in the entire world -- think of this -- where the six largest automakers call home,\" he said.\n\nIn a statement, Honda Canada spokesperson Ken Chiu declined to confirm the company's plans, but said Honda is \"considering a number of initiatives and is in contact with governments at all levels as we move into the electrified era.\"\n\nChiu added that, \"in order to achieve our 2040 electrification target of 100 per cent electrified vehicles, we are considering various options to increase local production capacity, however we have nothing further to share at this time.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt Queen's Park, provincial Economic Development Minister Vic Fedeli was tight-lipped while touting \"the largest Canadian auto announcement ever.\"\n\n\"It's very exciting,\" said Fedeli, declining to even specifically mention the word Honda due to commercial sensitivities.\n\n\"We've never talked about any of our prospects by name but I would say the scenario is that we do have incentives,\" said the minister, referring to tax breaks and other sweeteners Queen's Park and Ottawa have put in place.\n\n\"That's where we think our tax dollars are best invested because we had 100,000 jobs that were at risk in the auto sector,\" he said, pointing to competition stateside.\n\n\"Not only did we save those 100,000 jobs, we've created tens of thousands more.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAsked about Ford of Canada recently slashing EV production in Oakville, Fedeli emphasized \"no money is distributed to any company until they've met their hiring goals and their construction goals.\"\n\nBloomberg first reported that a deal with Honda, which has long been rumoured, was expected to be announced this week.\n\nHonda's potential $18.4 billion auto assembly and EV battery factory would expand the complex 107 kilometres north of Toronto that currently makes gasoline-powered Civics and CR-Vs.\n\nAsked about that dollar figure, a federal government source declined to share specifics but said the total is \"in the ballpark\" of what will be announced with Honda this week.\n\nFedeli would only say that Ontario's overall $28 billion in EV investments would balloon to around $43 billion within the next week, suggesting a $15 billion Honda investment.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTo Flavio Volpe, head of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers' Association, the prospect such a deal is \"incredible.\" He said it would be an even bigger coup after the federal government signalled there would be no more direct subsidies like those it used to land EV factories from Stellantis, Volkswagen and Northvolt in Quebec.\n\nVolpe pointed to a new measure unveiled in the recent federal budget, which promised a new \"electric vehicle supply chain investment tax credit\" worth 10 per cent of the cost that companies put toward buildings used in \"key segments\" of the industry.\n\nVolpe said that tax credit seems tailor-made for major companies like Honda, and noted that Ottawa and the Ontario and Quebec governments are also still trying to court Toyota -- another major Japanese automaker -- to set up electric vehicle manufacturing in Canada.\n\nIf the tax credit helped attract a big company like Honda, that would mark a significant victory for the government's shift from direct subsidies to a simpler offering that doesn't need to be negotiated with the same depth.\n\nThat could position Canada to better compete for jobs and manufacturing in the sector with the United States, which has its own massive suite of incentives under President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act.\n\n\"I've got to give them full credit, no pun intended, on (potentially) pulling in a big fish -- maybe the biggest -- with credits,\" Volpe said.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alex_ballingall@thestar.com", "name": "Alex {"uri": "8097069846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:06:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:06:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:05:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/2917938-honda-to-set-up-11-bln-electric-vehicle-battery-plants-in-canada", "title": "Honda to set up $11 bln electric vehicle, battery plants in Canada | Business", "body": "Although global EV demand has slowed, Honda executive Shinji Aoyama told reporters the supply network would help Honda achieve its goal for all of its North American sales to be either EVs or fuel cell vehicles by 2040. Honda said it expects to contribute 60%-70% of the total investment, with the rest coming from joint venture partners and Ontario government subsidies.\n\nHonda Motor plans to invest C$15 billion ($11 billion) in new EV and battery production plants alongside its existing facilities in Ontario, it said on Thursday, the Japanese automaker's largest ever investment in Canada. The investment, announced by company executives and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, signals Honda's expectation for more growth in North American demand for EVs.\n\nLike other Japanese car companies, Honda has been a relative latecomer to EVs, and is now pushing to better compete with fast-moving Chinese rivals. In Canada, it intends to produce essential EV components through joint ventures with companies such as Asahi Kasei , setting up a production system that covers everything from materials to finished vehicles.\n\nOperations are targeted to start by 2028, with annual production capacity estimated to be a maximum of 240,000 EVs and 36 gigawatt-hours for batteries. Although global EV demand has slowed, Honda executive Shinji Aoyama told reporters the supply network would help Honda achieve its goal for all of its North American sales to be either EVs or fuel cell vehicles by 2040.\n\nHonda said it expects to contribute 60%-70% of the total investment, with the rest coming from joint venture partners and Ontario government subsidies. Support from the federal Canadian government and Ontario could total around C$5 billion, Trudeau's office said. Details of the investment are due to be finalised later this year.\n\nThe EV and battery plants will be constructed adjacent to existing four-wheeled vehicle and engine plants and the total workforce will increase by around 1,000 people from 4,200 now, Honda said. It also announced a plan to work with South Korean steel giant POSCO for the production of battery cathode materials, and with Asahi Kasei to make separators.\n\nBy handling everything from material development to vehicle assembly in Ontario - including bringing battery production in house and sourcing locally - Honda expects to reduce costs by more than 20% from current methods. Canada has wooed companies involved in all parts of the EV supply chain to bolster its manufacturing heartland in Ontario as the world seeks to cut carbon emissions.\n\n\"Honda's investment is a vote of confidence in Canada, in Canadian auto workers, and in our manufacturing sector. Together, we're creating good-paying jobs, growing our economy, and keeping our air clean,\" Trudeau said. North America accounts for approximately 30% of Honda's global four-wheeled vehicle sales.\n\nHonda is currently overhauling facilities at its U.S. plant in Ohio, with an investment of $700 million, and constructing a battery plant in a joint venture with LG Energy Solution for $4.4 billion. ($1 = 1.3676 Canadian dollars) (Additional reporting by David Ljunggren in Ottawa; Editing by David Dolan, Mark Potter, Elaine Hardcastle)\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is building an electric vehicle battery plant in Alliston, Ont., part of a $15-billion investment.\n\nSenior sources with information on the project have told The Canadian Press that Honda is also retooling its assembly plant in Alliston to produce fully electric vehicles.\n\nThe $15-billion project includes the retooled plant, an electric vehicle battery plant in close proximity, as well as two key battery parts facilities located elsewhere in Ontario.\n\nThere will likely be some capital investment from at least one level of government, but the sources say the deal does not involve production subsidies, which were used to woo two other automakers to build battery plants in Ontario instead of the United States with its incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act.", "source": {"uri": "8097041130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:45:31", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:45:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:45:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/04/26/mil-osi-translation-honda-to-build-canadas-first-comprehensive-electric-vehicle-supply-chain-creating-thousands-of-jobs-in-ontario/", "title": "MIL-OSI Translation: Honda to build Canada's first comprehensive electric vehicle supply chain, creating thousands...", "body": "From the extraction of critical minerals to the manufacturing of automobiles and batteries, Canadian businesses and workers are attracting unprecedented investments that help maintain and create jobs, grow our economy and keep our air clean. Over the past four years, auto and battery manufacturers have announced investments of more than $31 billion in electric vehicle manufacturing across Canada. They're looking for a reliable partner with world-class talent, and that's exactly what we have to offer.\n\nAnd the world notices.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau and Ontario Premier Doug Ford today welcomed the significant investment of approximately $15 billion announced by Honda Canada to create Ontario's first-ever electric vehicle supply chain complete coverage of Canada.\n\nAs part of this large-scale project, four new manufacturing plants will be created in Ontario. Honda will build an innovative, world-class electric vehicle assembly plant - the first of its kind for Honda Motor Co., Ltd. - as well as a new standalone battery manufacturing plant at its Alliston, Ontario facility. Finally, to complete the supply chain, Honda will also build a processing plant for cathode active materials and cathode active material precursors, through a joint venture with POSCO Future M Co., Ltd., as well as a separator factory, as part of a joint venture with the Asahi Kasei Corporation. When fully operational in 2028, the new assembly plant will have a production capacity of 240,000 vehicles per year.\n\nHonda's investments in building an electric vehicle assembly plant and battery manufacturing plant in Alliston will create more than a thousand good-paying manufacturing jobs in Ontario. The cathode active materials and cathode active material precursors processing plant and the separator plant will help create thousands of additional direct and indirect jobs in Ontario and across Canada, particularly during the construction phase and across Ontario's major automotive parts supplier and research and development ecosystems.\n\nThis investment represents a strong vote of confidence in the highly skilled workers, strong economies and competitive business environments of Canada and Ontario.\n\nCanada's auto sector, which drives innovation and creates good middle-class jobs, is an engine of economic growth. With the demand for electric vehicles continuing to grow, we will attract even more investment. Thus, our automobile, battery manufacturing and battery materials production industries will be among the global leaders in the entire electric vehicle supply chain, and they will contribute to economic growth and creating opportunities today and for generations to come.\n\n\"Today's announcement will change the face of Canadian manufacturing. Honda's investment is a vote of confidence in Canada, Canadian auto workers and the entire Canadian auto sector. Together, we create good-paying jobs, grow our economy and keep our air clean. \"\n\n\"The unprecedented $15 billion investment announced today by Honda delivers on our government's promise to revive our manufacturing sector as part of our plan to rebuild Ontario's economy, creating thousands of well-paying union jobs and providing economic benefits to workers and families across the province. From the abundance of our critical minerals in the Ring of Fire region to our highly skilled workforce, Ontario has what it takes to create the jobs of the future, as a global leader of electric vehicle manufacturing, and deliver better jobs and higher wages to our world-class workers. \"\n\n\"Canada has the talented workers, raw materials, clean electricity and specialized production capabilities needed to build electric vehicles. Today's announcement \u2012 Honda's largest investment in North America \u2012 aims to seize the opportunity this represents for the benefit of Canadian workers. We are building the Canadian advantage in electric vehicles by establishing a complete supply chain ecosystem, from raw materials to battery manufacturing to car assembly. In doing so, we ensure that workers benefit today and for decades to come. \"\n\n\"At a time when the world is turning to more sustainable vehicles, Canada is seizing the opportunity to position itself among the world leaders in manufacturing the cars of tomorrow. This unprecedented investment by Honda demonstrates the attractiveness and competitiveness of the commercial environment in Canada. With its highly skilled workforce, clean energy, abundance of critical minerals, access to markets and growing electric vehicle ecosystem, Canada has everything companies like Honda need to grow. \"\n\n\"Honda's unprecedented investment, which we have been working towards for several years, represents a vote of confidence in Ontario's status as a global leader in the production and development of electric vehicles, batteries and battery materials. As our province continues to build a fully integrated, end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain, Honda's investment will play a vital role in advancing the innovative technologies that will define the future of automotive design, all ensuring thousands of good-paying jobs for workers in Alliston and across the province. Thank you, Honda, for choosing Ontario. \"\n\n\"Honda of Canada Manufacturing has one of the best automotive manufacturing plants in the world, and for nearly forty years our work has been guided by determination, innovation and an unwavering desire to evolve. Today's announcement represents an unprecedented investment by a manufacturer in the Canadian automotive industry. It demonstrates the expertise of our highly skilled industry collaborators, who have earned a global reputation for manufacturing excellence, and demonstrates that Honda recognizes the long-term appeal of Canada's electric vehicle manufacturing ecosystem. \"\n\nIn Budget 2024, the federal government announced plans to introduce a new 10% electric vehicle supply chain investment tax credit to attract investment in at least three segments of the supply chain :\n\nthe assembly of electric vehicles.\n\nthe production of batteries for electric vehicles.\n\nthe production of cathode active materials.\n\nThe new electric vehicle supply chain investment tax credit is the government's sixth major investment tax credit. It complements the 30% tax credit for investment in clean technology manufacturing. The government intends to prioritize all major investment tax credits.\n\nIt is estimated that Honda's new investments in eligible segments of the electric vehicle supply chain could benefit from up to $2.5 billion in federal support through two proposed tax credits, the Electric Vehicle Supply Chain Investment Tax Credit and the Clean Technology Manufacturing Investment Tax Credit.\n\nThe Ontario government will support these segments with $2.5 billion through various direct and indirect incentives.\n\nPreparatory work for Honda's new Alliston plant is expected to be completed in six months, at which time the company will be able to provide more details. Honda, the Government of Canada and the Government of Ontario are working collaboratively to support this project.\n\nHonda's proposed comprehensive electric vehicle supply chain will include a new processing plant for cathode active materials and cathode active material precursors, in a joint venture with Korean battery materials producer POSCO Future M Co. , Ltd., as well as a new separator plant, in a joint venture with Japanese chemical manufacturer Asahi Kasei Corporation. These two factories will be located in Ontario, and announcements will be made later in the communities that will host them.\n\nThis project is part of Honda's efforts to achieve carbon neutrality. The company aims to sell only zero-emission electric vehicles in North America by 2040.\n\nHonda is a global automotive industry leader headquartered in Tokyo, Japan. The company was the first Japanese automaker to manufacture cars in Canada. It established Honda Canada in 1969 and began production in Alliston, Ontario, in 1986. These facilities - the only ones where Honda manufactures cars in Canada - currently include two automobile plants and an engine plant. They have the capacity to produce more than 400,000 vehicles and 190,000 engines per year. The company employs more than 4,200 people in Alliston and has a network of more than 280 dealerships across the country.\n\nThe governments of Canada and Ontario have already invested $131.6 million each to help Honda Canada retool its manufacturing facilities in Alliston to build the next generation of hybrid electric vehicles.\n\nThis is the latest in a series of unprecedented investments that Canada has attracted into its electric vehicle supply chain, from mining to manufacturing. Including Honda's new project, these investments now amount to more than $46 billion since 2020. They include the following:\n\n$7 billion from Northvolt Batteries North America for a new electric vehicle battery production plant in Saint-Basile-le-Grand and McMasterville, Quebec.\n\n$7 billion from Volkswagen for its first overseas electric vehicle battery production plant in St. Thomas, Ontario.\n\nMore than $5 billion from Stellantis and LG Energy Solution to create a joint venture for electric vehicle battery production in Windsor, Ontario.\n\n$1.8 billion from Ford to convert its assembly plant in Oakville, Ontario, into a battery electric vehicle manufacturing plant.\n\n$1.5 billion from Umicore to build a new world-class carbon-neutral factory in Loyalist Township, Ontario, specializing in the manufacturing of critical battery components for electric vehicles.\n\n$1.2 billion for the construction of a new battery materials production plant in B\u00e9cancour, Quebec, by a consortium formed by Ford Motor Company and Korean companies EcoProBM and SK On.\n\n$600 million for a cathode active materials processing plant to be built as a joint venture between General Motors and POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. in B\u00e9cancour, Quebec.\n\nIn Budget 2023, the government announced a new refundable clean technology investment tax credit of up to 30% of the costs of machinery and equipment used to manufacture or process clean technologies and extract , transform or recycle key critical minerals.\n\nThe Canadian automotive sector produces more than 1.5 million vehicles each year, or one every 21 seconds. It provides nearly 550,000 direct and indirect jobs, added $18 billion in 2023 to Canada's gross domestic product and is one of the country's largest export sectors. It is solidified by the presence of five automobile manufacturers: Stellantis, Ford, General Motors, Toyota and Honda.\n\nThe transportation sector is responsible for a quarter of emissions in Canada. The government has therefore set itself an ambitious objective, that is, for all vehicles sold in the country to be zero-emission vehicles by 2035. This objective is accompanied by support measures which include charging infrastructure and purchase incentives. .\n\nOverall electric vehicle sales are forecast to be more than three times larger in 2030 than in 2023, and Canada is well-positioned to be a big player in electric vehicle production.\n\nEDITOR'S NOTE: This article is a translation. {"uri": "2024-04-335346392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:50:28", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:50:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:50:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/Press+Releases/Honda+to+build+Canadas+first+comprehensive+electric+vehicle+supply+chain%2C+creating+thousands+of+new+jobs+in+Ontario/23116390.html", "title": "Honda to build Canada's first comprehensive electric vehicle supply chain, creating thousands of new jobs in Ontario", "body": "ALLISTON, ON, April 25, 2024 /CNW/ - From mining critical minerals to building cars and batteries, Canadian businesses and workers are attracting historic investments to help secure and create jobs, grow our economy, and keep our air clean. In the last four years, automotive and battery makers have announced more than $31 billion in investments in electric vehicle manufacturing across Canada. They want a reliable partner with world-class talent, and this is exactly what we have to offer.\n\nAnd the world is taking notice.\n\nThe Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau, and the Premier of Ontario, Doug Ford, today welcomed Honda Canada's milestone investment of approximately $15 billion to create Canada's first comprehensive electric vehicle supply chain, located in Ontario.\n\nThis large-scale project will see four new manufacturing plants in Ontario. Honda will build an innovative and world-class electric vehicle assembly plant - the first of its kind for Honda Motor Co., Ltd. - as well as a new stand-alone battery manufacturing plant at Honda's facilities in Alliston, Ontario. To complete the supply chain, Honda will also build a cathode active material and precursor (CAM/pCAM) processing plant through a joint venture partnership with POSCO Future M Co., Ltd. and a separator plant through a joint venture partnership with Asahi Kasei Corporation. Once fully operational in 2028, the new assembly plant will produce up to 240,000 vehicles per year.\n\nHonda's investments in an electric vehicle assembly plant and a battery manufacturing plant in Alliston will create over one thousand well-paying manufacturing jobs in Ontario, with the CAM/pCAM processing plant and separator plant helping to create thousands of additional direct and indirect jobs in Ontario and across Canada, including during the construction phase and across Ontario's leading auto parts supplier and research and development ecosystems.\n\nThis investment is a strong vote of confidence in Canada and Ontario's highly skilled workers, strong economies, and competitive business environments.\n\nCanada's auto sector has been an engine of economic growth, driving innovation and creating good middle-class jobs. As the demand for electric vehicles continues to grow, we will attract even more investment and position our auto, battery manufacturing, and battery material production industries as global leaders across the entire electric vehicle supply chain, to create economic growth and opportunities now and for generations to come.\n\n\"Today's announcement is a game changer for manufacturing in Canada. Honda's investment is a vote of confidence in Canada, in Canadian auto workers, and in our manufacturing sector. Together, we're creating good-paying jobs, growing our economy, and keeping our air clean.\"\n\n-- The Rt. Hon. Justin Trudeau, Prime Minister of Canada\n\n\"Today's historic $15 billion investment by Honda delivers on our government's promise to bring back manufacturing as part of our plan to rebuild Ontario's economy, with thousands of good-paying union jobs and economic benefits for workers and families across the province. From our abundant critical minerals in the Ring of Fire to our highly skilled workforce, Ontario has what it takes to secure the jobs of the future as the world leader in electric vehicle manufacturing, with better jobs and bigger paycheques for our world-class workers.\"\n\n-- The Hon. Doug Ford, Premier of Ontario\n\n\"Canada is home to the talented workers, raw materials, clean electricity, and specialized production capabilities needed to build electric vehicles. Today's announcement \u2012 Honda's largest investment in North America \u2012 is about seizing that opportunity for Canadian workers. We are securing Canada's electric vehicle advantage by building out the entire electric vehicle supply chain ecosystem, from raw materials to battery manufacturing to auto assembly lines \u2012 ensuring workers benefit today and for decades to come.\"\n\n-- The Hon. Chrystia Freeland, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance\n\n\"As the world shifts toward more sustainable vehicles, Canada is seizing the opportunity and positioning itself as a global leader when it comes to building the cars of the future. This historic investment by Honda is a testament to Canada's attractive and competitive business environment. With a highly skilled workforce, clean energy, an abundance of critical minerals, access to markets, and a flourishing electric vehicle ecosystem, Canada has everything that companies like Honda need to grow.\"\n\n-- The Hon. Fran\u00e7ois-Philippe Champagne, Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry\n\n\"Several years in the making, Honda's historic investment represents a vote of confidence in Ontario's status as a leading jurisdiction in the global production and development of electric vehicles, batteries, and battery materials. As our province continues to build a fully integrated end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain, Honda's investment will play an integral role in advancing the innovative technologies that will define the future of automotive design, while securing thousands of good-paying jobs for workers in Alliston and across the province. Thank you, Honda, for choosing Ontario.\"\n\n-- The Hon. Vic Fedeli, Ontario's Minister of Economic Development, Job Creation and Trade\n\n\"Honda of Canada Manufacturing is one of the premier automotive manufacturing facilities in the world and, for nearly forty years, our work has been guided by determination, innovation, and a relentless drive to evolve. Today's announcement is a historic investment by a manufacturer in the Canadian auto industry. It proudly honours the highly skilled associates who have earned a global reputation for manufacturing excellence and represents Honda's recognition of the long-term attractiveness of the Canadian electric vehicle manufacturing ecosystem.\"\n\n-- Jean Marc Leclerc, President and Chief Executive Officer, Honda Canada\n\nQuick Facts", "source": {"uri": "streetinsider.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8097095752", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:23:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:23:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:23:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.guideautoweb.com/en/articles/74269/", "title": "Honda Confirms Plans for $15B EV and Battery Plants in Ontario", "body": "Honda today confirmed that it plans to build a comprehensive electric vehicle value chain in Canada with an approximate investment of $15 billion, including investment by joint venture partners, to strengthen its EV supply system and capability to prepare for a future increase in EV demand in North America.\n\nThe governments of Canada and Ontario will contribute $2.5 billion apiece, representing a third of the Japanese automaker's investment. The money will come from performance-based initiatives available through the federal government's new Investment Tax Credits and provincial direct and indirect incentives.\n\n\"Today's announcement is a historic investment by a manufacturer in the Canadian auto industry,\" said Jean Marc Leclerc, President and CEO of Honda Canada. \"It proudly honours the highly skilled associates who have earned a global reputation for manufacturing excellence and represents Honda's recognition of the long-term attractiveness of the Canadian electric vehicle manufacturing ecosystem.\"\n\nThe future Honda EV plant and standalone Honda EV battery plant will be located in Alliston near the company's existing manufacturing facilities. There will also be a cathode active material and precursor (CAM/pCAM) processing plant through a joint venture partnership with POSCO Future, as well as a separator plant through a joint venture partnership with Asahi Kasei Corporation.\n\nHonda expects that EV production will begin in 2028. Once fully operational, the EV plant will have a production capacity of 240,000 EVs per year and the EV battery plant will have a capacity of 36 GWh per year.\n\nIn addition to securing the current employment level of 4,200 associates at its two existing manufacturing facilities in Ontario, Honda estimates it will add a minimum of 1,000new associates for the EV and EV battery manufacturing facilities. The investment in the new facilities will also create significant spinoff jobs across all sites, including in the construction sector.\n\nHonda has begun the process of evaluating the scope of its investment and completing negotiations with its joint venture partners. This work is expected to be finalized during the next six months and more details will be shared at that time.\n\nThe new facilities in Alliston will add to the Ohio EV hub that Honda is creating in the U.S. to serve as the foundation for future EV and EV battery production. It will be the largest deal in Canadian history. It'll be double the size of Volkswagen,\" he said, referring to a battery plant announced last year, for which the German automaker pledged Can$7 billion (US$5 billion) in investment.\n\nCanada in recent years has been positioning itself as an attractive destination for electric vehicle investment, touting tax incentives, renewable energy access and its rare mineral deposits.\n\nThe Honda plant, to be built an hour outside Toronto, in Alliston, will also produce electric-vehicle batteries, joining existing Volkswagen and Stellantis battery plants.\n\nIn January, when news of the deal first bubbled up in the Japanese press, the Nikkei newspaper estimated it would be worth Can$14 billion -- numbers backed up by Canadian officials recently.\n\nIn the federal budget announced last week, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government introduced a new business tax credit, granting companies a 10 percent rebate on construction costs for new buildings used in key segments of the electric vehicle supply chain.\n\nCanada's strategy follows that of the neighboring United States, whose Inflation Reduction Act has provided a host of incentives for green industry.\n\nHonda hopes to {"uri": "8094440445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "08:01:49", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T08:01:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T08:01:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/honda-alliston-announcement-preview-1.7182067", "title": "ANALYSIS | Table set for Honda's massive bet on Canada's electric vehicle sector | CBC News", "body": "When word of Honda's soon-to-be-announced electric vehicle investment leaked to Bloomberg News on Sunday, Ontario Premier Doug Ford saw an opening to boast about his government's success in getting into the automotive battery business.\n\n\"We've overtaken China and knocked them off the pedestal for the first time ever,\" he told the First Nations Major Project Coalition conference on Monday morning, referring to Canada's top spot in a recent global supply chain ranking. \"That's absolutely huge.\"\n\nExpect more superlatives when Honda Canada makes its official announcement in Allison, Ont. on Thursday, as government and industry leaders celebrate the fact that the company behind some of Canada's most popular models is settling in for the long haul in Canada's EV sector.\n\n\"This may be Honda's biggest bet anywhere on the planet,\" Flavio Volpe, the president of the Automotive Manufacturers Association of Canada, told CBC News. He called it a \"double down\" on Canada and \"an announcement that I think will be heard around the world.\"\n\nHonda doesn't make speculative bets, he said. \"They've been in Canada for almost 40 years. They've never retreated, they've never gone back. This is, for Canadian suppliers, an extremely bankable customer to get.\"\n\nEnjoying the hype this announcement is generating means ignoring, for the time being, the fact that most of Northern Ontario's critical minerals are years (if not decades) away from powering all the new EVs Canadians will be federally mandated to purchase after 2035 to meet federal carbon emissions targets.\n\nIt means overlooking the fact that Ford's government remains well short of the Indigenous partnerships and permissions it will need to fulfil its Ring of Fire mining aspirations. It means dismissing the failure to date of early consumer incentives and spiking spring gas prices to set off a rush of EV sales, and the fact that many of the new EVs on Ontario's roads were imported from a Tesla gigafactory in Shanghai.\n\n\"Here in Ontario, we've become a world leader in the electric vehicle revolution,\" Ford bragged.\n\nFord said the deal coming this week will be \"double the size of Volkswagen.\"\n\nThe $7 billion VW battery plant now under construction in St. Thomas, Ont. covers roughly 150 hectares -- over 200 football fields. It's \"like a city in itself,\" Ford said.\n\nIt was not clear from Ford's comments if he meant Honda's new operation will cover twice the acreage of the Volkswagen plant, or if its investment is double the size of the Volkswagen deal. Either way, it's historic.\n\nIn January, the Japanese news outlet Nikkei was the first to report Honda was considering an investment of 2 trillion yen (about $18 billion Cdn) to start up an EV supply chain in Canada.\n\nFord's economic development minister, Vic Fedeli, appeared to confirm Thursday's figures could be on that scale when speaking to reporters at Queen's Park on Monday.\n\nOntario's EV investments \"went from zero to $28 billion in three years,\" he said, before hedging slightly.\n\n\"If the premier, if his comments are correct,\" he added, \"then next week we'll be announcing $43 billion in EV, or a number in and around there.\"\n\nSo is Honda about to invest $15 billion in Ontario?\n\nNot so fast. In a subsequent report published Tuesday, Nikkei said Honda was preparing a one-trillion yen announcement (approximately $8.8 billion.)\n\nAs the premier told his Monday audience, \"stay tuned.\"\n\nThe timing of Honda's announcement was a business decision -- but it's a happy coincidence for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau that it fell in the midst of his ministers' post-budget marketing tour.\n\nOnly a few months after Trudeau signalled that the federal government was running out of money for automotive subsidies -- prompting fears that Toyota Canada would hit the brakes on further Ontario expansion -- a change in government tactics apparently paid off.\n\nCanada's share of North American manufacturing could have been in jeopardy if the federal and provincial governments hadn't stepped up with both investment tax credits and production subsidies to compete with the Inflation Reduction Act introduced by U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\nThose billions were enough to land Ontario its first two battery plants: the VW plant in St. Thomas and the Stellantis facility in Windsor. But the Trudeau government warned at the time that their production subsidies aren't sustainable.\n\nThe sweeteners offered to land this Honda deal are more predictable because they're based on the value of Honda's investment, not future production levels.\n\nIn the 2023 federal budget, the Liberals introduced a clean manufacturing investment tax credit that rebates 30 per cent of the cost of new machinery and equipment. Its implementation legislation, C-59, has yet to pass; the Liberals hope it receives royal assent by June.\n\nLast week, the 2024 federal budget introduced a ten per cent electric vehicle supply chain investment tax credit to offset the cost of buildings. Companies receiving the tax credit must invest in three parts of the EV supply chain: EV assembly, battery production and production of cathode active material for those batteries.\n\nFinance Minister Chrystia Freeland's department took the lead in federal talks with Honda; her budget forecasts a $80 million expenditure on this tax credit over the next five years. The federal government has hinted it anticipates about $800 million in investment on eligible buildings between now and 2029.\n\nHonda appears set to be the first -- and possibly the only -- carmaker to make the vertical investments required to access this credit, with an expansion of its facilities in Alliston as well as other yet-to-be announced expansions in Ontario.\n\nCBC News has not confirmed that a site earmarked for EV battery production in St. Clair township near Sarnia, Ont. is part of Honda's negotiations. Fedeli said Monday that land in Wilmot township near Waterloo, Ont. was not part of Honda's plans.\n\nQuebec's economy minister, Pierre Fitzgibbon, told reporters at the National Assembly Tuesday that he was in talks to land a piece of Honda's business at the industrial park in B\u00e9cancour, Que. where other automotive giants are setting up cathode materials manufacturing.\n\nFitzgibbon admitted he was outbid by Ontario.\n\nTo help attract EV investment, Ontario's 2023 provincial budget included a 10 per cent refundable corporate income tax credit for eligible investments in buildings, machinery and equipment, worth up to $2 million a year for individual corporations.\n\nThe Toronto Star has reported that when the Stellantis deal was in jeopardy, the federal government convinced the Ford government to pile on more provincial subsidies in return for federal cooperation on the environmental assessments required to build Highway 413.\n\nIt's not known whether a similar last-minute squeeze happened in the Honda talks. Ontario Finance Minister Peter Bethlenfalvy's statement in reaction to the April 16 federal budget nodded to this Highway 413 quid pro quo and revived Ontario's demand for the federal government to \"eliminate duplicative reviews and processes that are slowing down\" Ring of Fire projects.\n\nVolpe said the new rules hammered out during the NAFTA renegotiation talks anticipated the transition to electrified powertrain products and batteries by making sure carmakers couldn't source components offshore (China, mainly) without risking tariffs.\n\nDuring a 2023 visit to Canada, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida called China a \"central challenge.\"\n\nGeopolitically, Japan is far more comfortable working with Canada to source the critical minerals its automotive engineers need.\n\nLast September, Japan's economy, trade and investment minister Yasutoshi Nishimura visited Ottawa with a delegation of Japanese businesspeople from its battery supply chain association (BASC) and corporations like Panasonic Energy, Asahi-Kasei, Mitsubishi, Mitsui and Sumitomo. They signed memoranda of cooperation with Canadian companies about sharing technology and business intelligence.\n\nThis week's Honda announcement will be Canada's biggest EV investment deal so far. But it wasn't the first and it's not expected to be the last.\n\nNow that Honda's seen enough to place its bet and become Ontario's third EV battery maker, attention will turn to whether Toyota might reconsider becoming the fourth -- and whether Canada's clean power grids can accommodate more ambition.\n\n\"Every single car company is spending all of their future R&D dollars on electrified product or fuel cell project product, anything that's zero emission,\" Volpe said, dismissing the naysayers who've lost faith due to slow consumer sales.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8097112122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:35:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:35:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:34:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://arstechnica.com/cars/2024/04/honda-to-spend-11-billion-on-four-ev-factories-in-north-america/", "title": "Honda to spend $11 billion on four EV factories in North America", "body": "The new facilities are in addition to the previously announced EV hub in Ohio.\n\nHonda announced today that it will spend $11 billion to expand its electric vehicle manufacturing presence in North America. The Japanese automaker already has a number of factories in the US, Mexico, and Canada, and it's this last one that will benefit from the expansion, with four EV-related plants planned for Ontario.\n\nHonda says it has begun evaluating requirements for what it's calling an \"innovative and environmentally responsible\" EV factory as well as a standalone EV battery plant, both in Alliston, Ontario, which is already home to Honda's two existing Canadian manufacturing facilities.\n\nAdditionally, the automaker wants to set up another two sites as joint ventures. One will be a plant that processes cathode active materials and their precursors -- the various elements like nickel and manganese that are combined with lithium in lithium-ion batteries -- set up in a partnership with POSCO Future M, a South Korean battery material and chemical company. (POSCO is already working with General Motors on another joint venture battery precursor material facility in Betancour, Quebec, that is supposed to become operational in 2026.)\n\nA second joint venture will be a partnership with Asahi Kasei, which will manufacture battery separators, the material that keeps the anode and cathode apart. The locations of these two joint ventures have not yet been announced.\n\nHonda thinks it will be able to start making EVs in Ontario in 2028 and says the assembly plant will have the capacity to build 240,000 EVs per year. Meanwhile, the battery plant is planned to have an annual output of 36 GWh.\n\n\"Honda is making progress in our global initiatives toward the realization of our 2050 carbon neutrality goal,\" said Honda CEO Toshihiro Mibe. \"In North America, following the initiative to establish our EV production system capability in the US, we will now begin formal discussions toward the establishment of a comprehensive EV value chain here in Canada, with the support of the governments of Canada and Ontario. We will strengthen our EV supply system and capability with an eye toward a future increase in EV demand in North America.\"\n\nThese investments in EV manufacturing by Honda are in addition to $700 million that it has spent retooling some of its factories in Ohio for electrification, plus a joint venture battery factory with LG Energy Solutions, also in Ohio, that has risen in cost to $4.4 billion. Honda says it expects to begin production of an electric sedan, shown off at CES earlier this year, in Ohio in late 2025. The brand currently has a single EV for the US market -- the Honda Prologue -- which shares one of GM's Ultium platforms. {"uri": "2024-04-334237343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/honda-set-announce-mega-ev-161300327.html", "title": "Honda set to announce mega EV and battery complex Thursday, says source", "body": "Honda Motor Co. Ltd. is set to announce that it will build a new electric-vehicle and battery manufacturing operation in Canada on Thursday morning in Alliston, Ont., according to a source familiar with the matter.\n\nTwo other sources said they expect the Japanese automaker to make an announcement this week, and added that it will be the largest EV and battery complex in Canada ever announced.\n\nHonda has confirmed it is holding discussions with \"all levels of government\" in Canada and considering expanding its local operations, but declined to comment further.\n\nA spokesperson for Simcoe County -- where Alliston is located -- also declined to comment on any proposed plans, but described Honda as \"an important partner, providing thousands of jobs to people across the county while investing in our communities.\"\n\nHonda currently manufactures its CRV and Civic models in Alliston -- about 85 kilometres north of Toronto -- and has said it plans to produce only electrified vehicles by 2040.\n\nThe announcement could mark a shift in clean technology incentive policy in Canada. In recent years, the federal government wooed Volkswagen AG and Stellantis NV to build battery cell manufacturing plants by offering lucrative production tax credits, similar to what would be available in the United States under the Inflation Reduction Act.\n\nThose were specific deals negotiated with VW and Stellantis.\n\nShift in EV incentives\n\nBut sources said the federal government is wooing Honda through different incentives. The 2024 federal budget, released last week, proposes a new Electric Vehicle Supply Chain tax credit of 10 per cent on the cost of any building.\n\nThe credit would be effective until 2032, decline to five per cent in 2033 and 2034, and then expire. The budget estimated it would cost $80 million over five years, plus an additional $1.02 billion between 2029-30 and 2034-35.\n\nTo be eligible, a company must claim the Clean Technology Manufacturing investment tax credit -- which is a 30 per cent credit on applicable new machinery and equipment -- in three segments of the supply chain: EV assembly, EV battery production and cathode active material production.\n\nA company can invest in only two of the three segments if it owns a minority interest in a company that invests in the third segment.\n\nThat tax policy, introduced in the 2023 budget, contains a proposed sunset clause of 2035.\n\nSo far, neither tax proposal has been passed into law.\n\nSources also said the federal government is interested in moving away from one-off deals with individual companies for production tax credits, and towards a more open policy that companies can claim for making investments in Canada.\n\nGM, Ford could tap tax credit\n\nThat would mean other automakers, including General Motors Co. and Ford Motor Co., which already have investments in the EV supply chain, could also eventually be eligible for the 10 per cent tax credit proposed in the 2024 budget.\n\nFor example, GM assembles BrightDrop EV at its CAMI plant in Ingersoll, Ont., and is building a cathode active material plant in B\u00e9cancour, Que. It could qualify for the tax credit by either building a battery cell manufacturing plant, or by owning a minority interest in a company that builds a battery plant in Canada.\n\nFord has proposed retooling its Oakville, Ont., assembly plant so it can produce EVs.\n\nSources said Honda may receive other incentives as well. The federal government has not always immediately disclosed the details of its deals with automakers investing in the battery and EV supply chain.\n\nThere are also provincial incentives in the form of loans and direct support, which when combined with the federal incentives collectively amount to more than $1 billion across a half-dozen projects.\n\nOntario's Ministry of Economic Development, Job Creation and Trade said via email that the province has attracted more than $28 billion in EV and battery supply chain-related investments in the past three years.\n\nA spokesperson said the ministry does not discuss specific prospective projects, but noted: \"We are grateful for Honda's longstanding history in Ontario, and will continue to seek out opportunities to promote job growth and ensure Ontario remains a competitive jurisdiction.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo!
